This spot high in the starting zone is much shallower than other areas on the same slope where more wind loading occurs, likely due to wind scouring and frequent sluffs. I was out looking for thinner areas to see how our recent warm-up had effected such zones.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Sond +

Pit was located in a snowfield in a pocket in the lee from W winds underneath a rollover. On the rollover (above the pit) were exposed rocks and trees as well as trees exposed 10m below the pit. Unbreakable ice crust 82cm down with many ice crusts within upper 82cm. Potentially caused by rain entering snowpack above pit location on exposed ground and traveling downhill through snow along preexisting layers.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Toured from Eaglecrest parking lot up Mt. Troy on 3/15/19. Temps just at/below freezing – rain on the drive up and snow at the parking lot. Overcast sky, light and variable wind, and slight snow, approximately 1 cm/hour. Followed traditional skin route to safety meadows, then approached summit. Dug a pit approximately 2700 ft. Snow from last three storms and before all seemed well bonded – no failure on a compression test, and no failure or propagation on an extended column test. Near the summit, wind increased and visibility dropped. We observed significant cornices near the summit/ridgeline on the west aspects of Troy, at which point we transitioned and descended. Awesome skiing.
SW Kebnetjåkka lilltopp, Bäckravin, Stenigt underlag

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snow Pit for Pro 1 AAI course. Diamond Bowl skiers right side near the top. Post control pit no slides noted on slope. Down canyon (and variable) winds had deposited some side loading. An avalanche in Upper Elevator at a slightly higher elevation had slid with use of explosives approximately 1+ feet deep earlier in the day on a control route. No significant results on stability testing. I did find a Q1 shear just below the melt freeze crust around 65cm from bottom of pit while doing a shear test (while removing an ECT that had no results). This was my layer of concern given the depth and likelihood that the ECT was not effecting it.

Objective: Investigate Jan 17 Site: Open area in trees with small amount of snow sky view, ground covered by bushes.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 1kg AB on slope above broke small cornice but no avalanche. Slope previously failed Feb 15 HS-N-R4,D3-O 6'deep, 1300' wide and it seems that most of the depth hoar was taken in that event. It also left the upper most layer layer of depth hoar hardened as its now P hard and rounded. Feeling like this is the main reason for the good stability and we are finally feeling good about this area. We opened the slope to guided skiing today for the first time this season.
Deep snowpack for elevation less then 7000'

Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surprisingly good pack. Got a quote-on-quote fracture on CT22 where the weaker upper powder sort of crapped-out after being compressed. Hard to call it a true fracture. I thought the pack was remarkably stable given the recent snow. I'd have liked to have dug a few more pits to confirm these results, but the whole thing felt pretty good.
